subject: Best Practice for Tests ?

messageBody:
I've inherited a huge codebase which I'll be taking over development for; as soon as
possible, I want to put skeletal JUnit tests in place for every class; as I perform
refactorings, and as I introduce new functionality, my intention is to first flesh out
JUnit tests, before adding feature/refactoring.
 
This raises several questions, most of all related to what are the best practices
for keeping Unit Tests alongside code.
 
Options as I see them:
 
1.    A separate directory tree with a root note of test, the package structure of
      which reflects that of the codebase; keep the tests completely isolated from
      production code, the downside being that if I refactor code around packages,
      I have to remember to move tests as well; also, removes my ability to test
      private and protected methods..
 
2.    A 'test' directory in each package of the codebase, containing TestXXXX
      classes; with a TestXXXX class for each XXXX class in the package above.
      Again, can't test public/protected methods, and a little extra work is    
      required to remove tests from production code, but not that much.
 
3.    Actually make each class in the production code it's own test, ie put the
      JUnit testing code in the class itself.  This gives me access to protected
      and private methods, AND makes it easy to refactor and move tests around.
      Another upside is that the JUnit plugin for Together UML will create all
      these test skeletons for me in this manner.  Downside (and I see it as a
      pretty big downside) is that my JUnit tests are all but impossible to remove
      from my production code.
 
Has anyone got any thoughts on this problem ?    Anyone been in a similar
situation, and got suggestions they could offer ?
 
Cheers,
 
Steven
